title: English Bridge
text:
The English Bridge is a masonry <a href="arch%20bridge">arch</a> viaduct, crossing the <a href="River%20Severn">River Severn</a> in <a href="Shrewsbury">Shrewsbury</a>, <a href="Shropshire">Shropshire</a>. The present bridge is a 1926 rebuilding and widening (re-using the original masonry) of <a href="John%20Gwynn%20%28architect%29">John Gwynn</a>'s design, completed in 1774. A bridge is known to have stood at this spot since at least <a href="Norman%20Conquest">Norman</a> times. Historically, it was known as the "Stone Bridge". It is a <a href="Grade%20II%2A%20listed">Grade II* listed</a> building.
The original Norman bridge consisted of five arches and a timber causeway. A large tower stood on the East bank, housing a gate and a <a href="drawbridge">drawbridge</a>. The bridge also supported several shops and houses. Building work on Gwynn's replacement bridge started on 29 June 1769, and comprised seven <a href="semicircle">semicircular</a> arches, long. This bridge cost £16,000. The <a href="span%20%28architecture%29">span</a> central arch was built high, to provide headroom to watercraft, but this resulted in steep approaches.
As a result, a new design was put forward in 1921 by Arthur W. Ward, the Borough Surveyor. This lowered all the arches, converting the central one into a <a href="circular%20segment">segmental</a> arch, reducing the height of the roadway by . The new bridge was to be wide, more than twice as wide as Gwynn's structure (of 23 and a half feet width). It cost £86,000 and was formally opened on 26 October 1927 by <a href="Mary%20of%20Teck">Queen Mary</a>, although it had been completed the previous year. Ward's bridge reused the old masonry, each stone carefully numbered, as well as a quantity of new stonework. Concrete was used to 'saddle' the arches and in the foundations.
The bridge is one of two bridges carrying the main east-west route over the Severn as it loops around Shrewsbury; the <a href="Welsh%20Bridge%20%28Shrewsbury%29">Welsh Bridge</a> is its counterpart on the other side of the town. Despite the names, both bridges are in <a href="England">England</a>, but the Welsh Bridge is on the side closer to <a href="Wales">Wales</a>.
<a href="Thomas%20Telford">Thomas Telford</a>'s Holyhead Road, dating from 1815 and connecting <a href="London">London</a> to the main sea-crossing to <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>, used the English Bridge to cross the Severn here. The road's modern successor, the <a href="A5%20road%20%28Great%20Britain%29">A5</a>, now bypasses Shrewsbury and the bridge's main role today is to connect the centre of Shrewsbury with the <a href="Belle%20Vue%2C%20Shrewsbury">Belle Vue</a> and <a href="Shrewsbury%20Abbey">Abbey Foregate</a> areas of the town.
